keccak

Class KeccakSponge

  • java.lang.Object
    • keccak.KeccakSponge
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.function.Function<byte[],byte[]>, java.util.function.UnaryOperator<byte[]>

    public final class KeccakSponge
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.function.UnaryOperator<byte[]>
    The Keccak sponge function for cryptographic hashing.

    An object of this type is immutable, and can be freely shared and reused.

    The sponge function represented by this code is entirely based on the Keccak sponge function family created by Guido Bertoni, Joan Daemen, Michaël Peeters, and Gilles Van Assche. Detailed specifications are defined by The Keccak Reference version 3.0 [January 2011].

    The Keccak sponge function powers the SHA-3 hash functions, and the related SHAKE extended output functions, both standardised by FIPS PUB 202 [August 2015]. For convenience, these standardised instances of the Keccak sponge function have been made available in the companion class FIPS202.

    See Also:
    FIPS202

    • Constructor Detail

      • KeccakSponge

        public KeccakSponge(int bitrate,
                    int capacity,
                    java.lang.String suffixBits,
                    int outputLength)
        Constructs a Keccak sponge function with the given parameters. The resulting KeccakSponge object is immutable and can be safely shared and reused.

        The bitrate is the maximum number of bits in each block while absorbing the input message into the Keccak sponge, and while squeezing the sponge to generate the resulting hash result. After each block has been absorbed or squeezed, the Keccak sponge state will be permuted. (NOTICE: Currently support is only implemented for bitrates which are exactly divisible by 8.)

        The capacity is the number of additional bits (on top of the bitrate) in the sponge permutation state. The sum of the bitrate and the capacity is the total "width" of the sponge permutation state. The state width must be any of the values 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, or 1600, and so the sum of the bitrate and the capacity must be equal to one of these valid widths. (NOTICE: Currently support is only implemented for widths of 200 or greater.)

        The suffix bitstring (or "domain suffix") will be appended to any input message processed by this sponge function. Using a domain suffix allows different results to be returned for different applications, even when the input message and all other parameters are identical. For example, the SHA-3 hash functions all use a domain suffix of "01", the SHAKE extendable output functions use a domain suffix of "1111", and the RawSHAKE extendable output functions use a domain suffix of "11".

        The output length determines the length, in bits, of the hash result which will be generated. The output length can be any non-zero size, and the sponge will be squeezed repeatedly until the hash result is of the requested length. Bear in mind that (all other parameters remaining identical) varying the output length will change only the later bits of the hash result. For example, if using output length 256 and then output length 512, the first 256 bits will be identical in both hash results. For this reason, it is recommended that you not use different output lengths for the same input message. See NIST FIPS PUB 202 "Appendix A.2 Additional Consideration for Extendable-Output Functions" for a note about this.

        Parameters:
        bitrate - must be a number of bits greater than zero.
        capacity - must be a number of bits, greater than zero, such that the sum bitrate + capacity is a valid Keccak state "width".
        suffixBits - a String which can contain only digits "0" and "1". Can be an empty String if no domain suffix is required. Must not be null.
        outputLength - the hash output length in bits. Must be greater than zero.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the suffixBits parameter is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the parameters has been provided with an invalid value.

    • Method Detail

      • getBitrate

        public int getBitrate()
        Returns the bitrate of this KeccakSponge instance. The bitrate is the (maximum) number of bits within each block absorbed into or squeezed from the permutation state. After the absorption or squeezing of each block, the state is permuted using the Keccak-F algorithm.
        Returns:
        the bitrate in bits.

      • getCapacity

        public int getCapacity()
        Returns the capacity of this KeccakSponge instance. The capacity is the size, in bits, of the portion of the permutation state which is not modified by the absorption of a new input block (at least not immediately), and which is not copied in the squeezing of a new output block, but which is affected when the state is permuted.
        Returns:
        the capacity in bits.

      • getPermutationWidth

        public int getPermutationWidth()
        Returns the permutation width of this KeccakSponge instance. The width is the size of the permutation state in bits, and is equal to the sum of the bitrate and the capacity.
        Returns:
        the permutation width in bits.

      • getLaneLength

        public int getLaneLength()
        Returns the lane length of this KeccakSponge instance. The permutation state is composed of a 5×5 array of "lanes". The length of each lane is therefore the permutation state width divided by twenty-five.
        Returns:
        the length in bits of each lane.

      • getNumberOfRoundsPerPermutation

        public int getNumberOfRoundsPerPermutation()
        Returns the number of rounds per permutation of this KeccakSponge instance. When the Keccak state is permuted it executes a "round" of transformations (named theta, rho, pi, chi, and iota) multiple times. The number of rounds in each permutation depends upon the permutation width, and will be a quantity between twelve and twenty-four.
        Returns:
        the number of rounds in each permutation.

      • getSuffixBits

        public java.util.Optional<java.lang.String> getSuffixBits()
        Returns the domain suffix used by this KeccakSponge instance. The domain suffix is optional, but if a suffix is being used then it will be a String representing a bitstring (composed of only '0' and '1' digits) which will be appended to the input after the message bits but before the padding bits, prior to the start of the hash processing.

        Use of a domain suffix allows different Keccak applications to differentiate themselves. For example, SHA3 hash functions use a domain suffix of "01", SHAKE extendable-output functions use a domain suffix of "1111", and RawSHAKE uses "11". If this KeccakSponge instance does not use a domain suffix then this method will return Optional.empty().

        Returns:
        the domain suffix as an Optional<String>.

      • getOutputLengthInBits

        public int getOutputLengthInBits()
        Returns the length of the hash result which will be generated by this KeccakSponge.
        Returns:
        the output length in bits.

      • apply

        public byte[] apply(byte[] message)
        Applies this Keccak sponge function to the given message and returns the calculated hash result. Every bit contained by the byte array will be considered part of the input message. The returned byte array will contain all of the bits of the calculated hash.

        The given message byte array will not be modified by this method. However, to avoid problems, the message byte array should not be accessible to any other threads while it is being used to calculate the hash. If the message comes from a shared resource then take a copy and pass the copy to this method.

        The length, in bits, of the resulting hash will be equal to the output length configured for this KeccakSponge object, as returned by the method getOutputLengthInBits(). If the output length is not exactly divisible by eight then the last few bits of the final byte of the returned byte array will not be part of the hash result binary. For example, if the output length is 10 bits then this method will return a byte array which contains two bytes, and only the two least-significant bits of the second byte will actually be part of the hash result; the most-significant six bits of the second byte will not be part of the hash result binary.

        Specified by:
        apply in interface java.util.function.Function<byte[],byte[]>
        Parameters:
        message - a byte array which exactly represents the message. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        a byte array which contains the calculated hash.

      • apply

        public byte[] apply(int messageLengthInBits,
                    byte[] message)
        Applies this Keccak sponge function to the specified number of bits from the given message byte array and returns the calculated hash result. Only the first messageLengthInBits bits found within the provided message will be considered part of the input message to be hashed, and any subsequent bits will be ignored.

        Bits are taken first from the bytes with the lowest index, and from the bits with the lowest binary indices. For example, if the given message byte array contains two bytes, and the specified message length is ten bits, then all of the byte at array index zero will be included, and from the second byte only the bits at index zero (the least significant bit) and index one will be included. The most-significant six bits of the second byte will be ignored.

        The given message byte array will not be modified by this method. However, to avoid problems, the message byte array should not be accessible to any other threads while it is being used to calculate the hash. If the message comes from a shared resource then take a copy and pass the copy to this method.

        The length, in bits, of the resulting hash will be equal to the output length configured for this KeccakSponge object, as returned by the method getOutputLengthInBits(). If the output length is not exactly divisible by eight then the last few bits of the final byte of the returned byte array will not be part of the hash result binary. For example, if the output length is 10 bits then this method will return a byte array which contains two bytes, and only the two least-significant bits of the second byte will actually be part of the hash result; the most-significant six bits of the second byte will not be part of the hash result binary.

        Parameters:
        messageLengthInBits - the number of bits in the given byte array to be considered part of the message to be hashed. Must not be negative, and must not be larger than the total number of bits available in the given byte array.
        message - a byte array which contains all of the message bits, and possibly subsequent unwanted bits. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        a byte array which contains the calculated hash.

      • apply

        public byte[] apply(java.io.InputStream stream)
             throws java.io.IOException
        Applies this Keccak sponge function to every byte returned by the given InputStream and returns the calculated hash result. Every bit from every byte read from the stream will be considered to be part of the input message to be hashed.

        This method will return the hash result as a byte array. The length, in bits, of the resulting hash will be equal to the output length configured for this KeccakSponge object, as returned by the method getOutputLengthInBits(). If the output length is not exactly divisible by eight then the last few bits of the final byte of the returned byte array will not be part of the hash result binary. For example, if the output length is 10 bits then this method will return a byte array which contains two bytes, and only the two least-significant bits of the second byte will actually be part of the hash result; the most-significant six bits of the second byte will not be part of the hash result binary.

        Parameters:
        stream - an InputStream from which the message bytes should be read. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        a byte array which contains the calculated hash.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an IOException is thrown by any of the stream reading operations.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a summary of this Keccak sponge function. Do not rely on the format of the returned text; it may change in future. All of the data found in the summary can be retrieved directly from this object using dedicated methods, so there should never be any need to parse data out of the text returned by this method.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a String which summarises the settings of this KeccakSponge.
